title: How to Make Stamped Wrapping Paper

steps.headline: Cut a large potato in half.
steps.description: Do not peel the potato; this way, your fingers won't get wet as you use it. Keep in mind that you will not be able to rinse these stamps. If you want to use more than one color for a certain shape, you will need to make a new stamp using a new potato for each color that you wish to use.

steps.headline: Stick a cookie cutter into the potato.
steps.description: Position a small cookie cutter against the cut side of one potato half. Press the cookie cutter into the potato until it is half way in. You will be cutting around the cookie cutter, so it might be best to choose a simpler design.

steps.headline: Use a paring knife to cut the negative space out.
steps.description: Press the tip of your knife into the side of the potato until it bumps up against the wall of the cookie cutter. Cut your way around the cookie cutter.

steps.headline: Pull the cookie cutter out, and brush off any excess potato.
steps.description: You should now have raised shape in the center of your potato that is the same shape as your cookie cutter. This is your stamp.

steps.headline: Cut your wrapping paper down to the size you need, then spread it out on your work surface.
steps.description: Choose some blank wrapping paper, such as white or brown craft paper, or butcher paper. Spread the paper down on your work surface, then tape or weight down the corners.

steps.headline: Squeeze some paint onto a paper plate.
steps.description: Acrylic paint or tempera paint will work best for this. If you are using acrylic paint, make sure that you are using the watered-down kind that comes in a bottle. The kind that comes in a tube (like toothpaste) is much too thick for this kind of project. You can only use one color for these stamps. If you want to use more colors, make more stamps, and put the paint on a separate plate.

steps.headline: Dip your stamp into the paint.
steps.description: Spread it around until the stamp is coated with a thin layer of paint. Use the edge of a spoon to scrape off any excess paint. If you use too much paint, your design may turn out smudged.

steps.headline: Press your stamp against the paper.
steps.description: Keep pressing your stamp against the paper at various points until your design is complete. Every so often, dip your stamp into the paint to re-ink it. If you want to use a new color, it would be best to make a new stamp. Create layers and multicolored designs by allowing the paint to dry, then stamping more colors on top.

steps.headline: Wait for the paint to dry, then use the paper.
steps.description: Homemade wrapping paper is great for any gift, especially a homemade one.

methods.name: Using a Lint Roller and Craft Foam

steps.headline: Get a lint roller and peel off the first sheet to reveal a fresh sticky sheet.
steps.description: You will be sticking your shapes to this to make a stamp. Don't worry, this stamp will not be permanent. If you want to change the design later on, you can simply peel off the current sheet, and add more foam pieces to it. If you can't find one, you can use a rolling pin instead, and wrap tape (sticky-side-out) around it.

steps.headline: Cut some craft foam into shapes.
steps.description: Keep your shapes smaller than 1 by 2½ inches (2.54 by 6.35 centimeters). The simpler shapes you use, the better. The color of the craft foam does not matter. If this is for Christmas wrapping paper, consider cutting Christmas-tree shapes instead, and then using a skewer to poke holes into them to make the ornaments.

steps.headline: Press the pieces of craft foam against the lint roller.
steps.description: You don't need to use any glue, because they will stick to the adhesive. The handle part of your lint roller will be the bottom part of your design. Consider adding additional pieces. For example, a piece of baker's twine will add some nice movement to your pattern.

steps.headline: Spread your paper out on your work surface.
steps.description: Choose some white or brown craft paper or butcher paper. Cut the paper to the size you need, then spread it across your work surface. Tape down the corners, or weigh them down with paper weights.

steps.headline: Roll the lint roller across an ink pad until the foam stamps are covered.
steps.description: You will be rolling this stamp across your paper, so make sure that everything is evenly coated.

steps.headline: Roll the lint roller across your paper.
steps.description: Roll the roller across your paper from side to side. Start at the top of the paper and work your way down in horizontal rows. Re-ink your roller stamp whenever necessary.

steps.headline: Wait for the ink to dry, then use your paper.
steps.description: Hand-stamped wrapping paper is perfect for any gift, but it works especially well for handmade gifts for that final, special touch.

steps.headline: Get a block of linoleum meant for carving stamps.
steps.description: You can often find them in the print-making section of an arts and crafts store. They are usually a light pink color and relatively thin. They are often labeled as "carving blocks."

steps.headline: Sketch out your design using a pen.
steps.description: Unless you have carved stamps before, it would be a good idea to keep the design simple.

steps.headline: Fill in the areas you want to cut out.
steps.description: Leave the areas that you want to be "colored" blank. When you carve your stamp out, the raised areas will the parts that get stamped against your paper.

steps.headline: Use a stamp carving tool to carve out the outline of your design.
steps.description: These stamps look a little bit like wood carving tools, except that they are much smaller, and the metal part is curved. They are often labeled as "linoleum cutters."

steps.headline: Use the stamp carving tool to carve out the areas you filled in.
steps.description: Carve the design out a little bit at a time using a scooping motion. You don't have to carve very deep or evenly; keep in mind that any raised areas will pick up ink and show up on your paper.

steps.headline: Spread out your paper.
steps.description: Choose some brown or white craft  paper or butcher paper. Cut it down to the size you want, then spread it out on your work surface. Tape or weigh down the corners.

steps.headline: Press your stamp against an ink pad.
steps.description: You can also use paint meant for print making, tempera paint, or acrylic paint.

steps.headline: Press your stamp against the paper to create the design.
steps.description: Keep pressing the stamp until the paper is filled. Remember to re-ink your stamp when the design starts to look faded.

steps.headline: Wait for the ink or paint to dry, then use the paper.
steps.description: Use the paper to wrap gifts. It works especially well for handmade gifts because it will give them that final, special touch.

steps.headline: Dip cookie cutters into paint to create delicate outlines.
steps.description: Squeeze some acrylic paint or tempera paint onto a paper plate, then dip your cookie cutter into it. Press the cookie cutter against a sheet of blank wrapping paper to create a delicate, outlined design.

steps.headline: Use a pencil eraser and an ink pad to create a simple polka dot design.
steps.description: Get a brand-new pencil with an unused eraser. Press the eraser into an ink pad, then tap the eraser against a sheet of blank wrapping paper. Do this over and over to create a polka dot design.

steps.headline: Use leaves and paint to create an organic design.
steps.description: If you are using flat leaves, like maple leaves, apply the paint directly to the leaf using a paintbrush. If you are using a dimensional leaf, such as a spring of pine, squeeze some paint onto a paper plate first, then dip the pine sprig into the paint. Press the leaf against your wrapping paper, then pull it away. Acrylic paint or tempera paint would work best for this.

steps.headline: Use cut pieces of fruit to create an organic design.
steps.description: Choose a hard, textured fruit, such as an apple or lemon, and cut it in half. Squeeze some acrylic or tempera paint out onto a paper plate, then dip the fruit into the paint. Press the fruit against your wrapping paper, then pull it away. Some vegetables may also work for this. For example, a bunch of celery cut in half will give you a rose-like design.

steps.headline: Go simple with sponges.
steps.description: Get a plain, thin sponge and cut it into an interesting shape. Squeeze some acrylic or tempera paint onto a paper plate, then dip your sponge into it. Press the sponge against your wrapping paper, then pull it away. Be careful not to press the sponge too hard against the paper, or the paint may smudge.

steps.headline: Attach found objects to a block of wood, and use that as your stamp.
steps.description:
Squeeze some acrylic or tempera paint out onto a paper plate, then dip your stamp into it. Gently press your stamp against your wrapping paper, then pull it away. The options for creating a wood-block stamp are endless. Here are some ideas to get you started:
Wrap a piece of string a few times around a block of wood to create a striped design. Glue a piece of bubble wrap to a block of wood for a polka dot design. Glue a lace doily to a block of wood for a fancy design.

steps.headline: Use store-bought stamps if you are short on time.
steps.description: There is nothing wrong with using store-bought stamps. They come in all sorts of shapes and sizes. Simply buy a stamp and an ink pad, press the stamp against the ink pad, then tap it against your paper.

tyn: Using a Lint Roller and Craft Foam
Ink pad or acrylic or tempera paint

Press the cookie cutter against a sheet of blank wrapping paper to create a delicate, outlined design.

Do this over and over to create a polka dot design.
Use leaves and paint to create an organic design.
If you are using flat leaves, like maple leaves, apply the paint directly to the leaf using a paintbrush.

Press the leaf against your wrapping paper, then pull it away.

Some vegetables may also work for this.
For example, a bunch of celery cut in half will give you a rose-like design.

Get a plain, thin sponge and cut it into an interesting shape.

Attach found objects to a block of wood, and use that as your stamp.
Squeeze some acrylic or tempera paint out onto a paper plate, then dip your stamp into it.
Gently press your stamp against your wrapping paper, then pull it away.
The options for creating a wood-block stamp are endless.

Here are some ideas to get you started:
Wrap a piece of string a few times around a block of wood to create a striped design.
Glue a piece of bubble wrap to a block of wood for a polka dot design.
Glue a lace doily to a block of wood for a fancy design.
Use store-bought stamps if you are short on time.
There is nothing wrong with using store-bought stamps.
They come in all sorts of shapes and sizes.
Simply buy a stamp and an ink pad, press the stamp against the ink pad, then tap it against your paper.
